author: Jack Blanchard
title: Senior MPs demand Theresa May to join forces with Labour to solve social care crisis
text:
News Senior MPs demand Theresa May to join forces with Labour to solve social care crisis Three powerful select committee chairs from both sides of the commons have written a joint letter to the Tory PM demanding she works across party lines to solve the demographic timebomb facing the UK Share MPs from both sides of the Commons have called on Theresa May to work across party lines Share Get politics   
Senior MPs from both sides of the Commons have urged Theresa May to join forces with Labour and solve Britain’s social care crisis. 
Three powerful select committee chairs have written a joint letter to the Tory PM demanding she works across party lines to solve the demographic timebomb facing the UK. 
It comes amid dire warnings that her Government is doing nothing to address the fact people are living ever-longer lives and that soaring numbers of elderly people will need years of care and support before they die. 
The unprecedented letter, from Tory health committee chair Dr Sarah Wollaston, Labour communities committee chair Clive Betts and public accounts committee chair Meg Hillier, calls for a “review to find a way of funding social care sustainably for the long term.” Labour's Clive Betts (Photo: PA) Tory Sarah Wollaston (Photo: Andy Stenning / Daily Mirror) 
The MPs added: “We believe that can best be achieved if there is cross-party consensus, and therefore urge you to invite all parties to become involved in a review, which should begin as soon as possible. 
“Given the scale of rising demand, this immense challenge will face whichever party is in government over the coming decades.” 
A previous attempt at cross-party work on social care collapsed in acrimony before the 2010 election, after the Tories tried to score political points by accusing Labour of plotting a ‘death tax’ to raise extra funds. Labour's Meg Hillier (Photo: Getty) 
David Cameron then ordered an independent commission to consider the issue led by the economist Sir Andrew Dilnot, who proposed a new cap on people’s social care costs of £35,000. 
But the shameless Tory PM then simply kicked the whole report into the long grass. Read More Social care crisis threatens NHS implosion, warns Britain's top doctor who says services are "cracking" under pressure 
New PM Mrs May has proved no better since taking over last summer, with her Chancellor Philip Hammond failing to even mention social care in his first ‘mini-Budget’ in November. 
The calls for renewed cross-party working were welcomed last night by doctors, trade unions, care charities and health think-tanks who all warned action is urgently needed. 
Dr Mark Porter, chair of the British Medical Association, said: “The current crunch in health and social care is a direct result of years of inadequate funding, and politicians of all parties failing to take a long-term view on what needs to happen. Dr Mark Porter (Photo: Handout) 
“Now is the time to put politics to one side and reach a cross-party consensus on how to tackle this crisis.” 
Rehana Azam, national secretary of the GMB union, added: “Health and social care funding is arguably the most pressing issue facing our country - with a crisis of epic proportions looming in the very near future. 
“GMB welcomes this new pressure on Theresa May to confront the problem rather than burying her head in the sand - or passing the buck onto local authorities.” Video Loading Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now
